captions.text: Who could the guilty dog be, that ate a loaf of bread?

I know it's not Oakley, cause Oakley's in here. 
I'll let you out now though
I know it wasn't you.  Who could have done that?
Come on up here.  Come On.  Face the Music

What?  Well I know it wasn't you.
And I know it wasn't you!

I think it was!
Was it you?

Shiloh, did you do this?
Hey!  Hey!
Did you eat that loaf of bread?
Did you eat this loaf of bread Shi?

Pull your bed away from the wall.
Did you do this?  Hey?
I bet you didn't share any with Shelby!

We got . . oh look! Oakley found a crumb!
What's this! There's Bread crumbs
I cannot believe you ate a half a loaf of bread Shiloh.
I'm not really yelling at her.

Cause I know it wasn't you.  You didn't even give me that
guilty look when I walked in.
And you were in the box.
It was you!  You were a bad dog!
And it's white bread!  Not even real good for you!

Come over here, come over here.
This is where you were a bad dog.
Are you a bad dog?  Huh?  Hey!

Are you sorry?  Look at me!  Look at me 
when I am talking to you. You're in trouble!
You're in trouble. You're a bad

You ate all that bread!
Look it!  Look.
You didn't eat any of the plastic did you?
You just ripped open the bag.
You won't even look at me will you.
Them other dogs are going crazy!
Yeah it had to be you, cause you are guilty!
It's alright.  I won't really be mad at you.
Who can stay mad at that face.

How do you manage to look so cute
when you are in trouble?

Hm? How do you manage to look so cute?
How do you manage to look so cute when you are in trouble?
Next time you should at least share with your sisters.  Right?
That would be nice of her.
[Music] Turn around and roll over Shelby.  Sing a song with your sweet voice
Shiloh, you've been a good little girl.  Come and join us for a new adventure.
Lots of fun, Lots of walks, won't you come into our Siberian World. See Oakley run watch her dance in the sun.
Gone to the Snow Dogs, Gone to the Snow Dogs, Gone to the Snow Dogs [music fades out]

comments.text: Why is that husky in a cage barely half the size of himself?﻿
comments.author: Carl Minez

comments.text:
+Carl Minez
Adult dogs with separation anxiety will always act out when their people 
leave.  It's like a personality disorder that is just a part of who they 
are.  You have to deal with adult dogs on a case-by-case basis.
comments.author: Michele W

comments.text:
+Carl Minez
Some huskies get bored and may chew on electrical wires or the door jambs 
of your house.  Some are fearful by nature (and Oakley is a rescue, if I 
remember correctly), and prefer to be in their "den" when their people 
leave, especially if there are other dogs around.  As long as the dog can 
stand up in the crate, then it is the correct size.  I leave my husky out 
of her crate for 30 minutes when I'm not home, but any longer than that, I 
have to crate her for her own protection.  My doberman was crated till she 
was almost 2 years old, then I could leave her out for long durations 
because she lost the desire to chew on wires.
comments.author: Michele W

comments.text:
Alright, I'd recommend you to maybe read some literature and watch some dog 
training shows (Not Cesar Millan though).

A two year old adult dog should NOT have those kind of problems.

Do you leave your dog at home a lot? For how many hours? Do you take 
him/her for walks several times a day and how long? Are you actively 
training him/her in obedience?
comments.author: Carl Minez

comments.text:
cause huskies are crazy for at least 2 years.. you can't really leave them 
out up until then, even if I pretend to leave and come back in five 
minutes, there's pee and poo on the floor and he's in the kitchen trying to 
eat food.
He would NEVER DO THAT if we were home.
they are destructive! and it's not a CAGE we don't cage them  like a zoo 
animal. I put mine in there when we go grocery shopping, etc. and he sleeps 
in his some night when he's in one of those " as soon as you go to sleep im 
crawling out of the bed to find something to chew on" moods I can tell when 
he's up to something lol.
imaging leaving a toddler home alone!? no way. huskies are fluffy toddlers 
pretty much! so kennel is a much better option.. I think every dog owner 
should own one..
comments.author: Alexis Rose

comments.text: Then why do you need a cage?
comments.author: Carl Minez

huskies like to sleep in den like places anyway!! they love it. my husky

plus with my husky, the more room he has the more trouble he can get into!
when he was a puppy I wold even put the divider in, because he would just

haha

Sooo cute, but aren´t you reactions a little confusing for your dog? - you

comments.author: SzCa77

comments.author: eurikastock

comments.text:
+SzCa77 Dogs react to the tone of your voice and your body language not the 
actually words you say. For example we do not use the word come as a 
command for our dogs to come to us. We use a different word and they come 
to us every single time not because of the word we use but because of how 
we said it and they know that when we say that word they get the greatest 
treat of all, their caviar so to speak. When our dogs do something we are 
not happy with we have never used bad dog. In our house (and from what I 
have seen of these video's they don't either) bad dog means they did 
something naughty but not something bad. Bad dog does not have a negative 
connection to them. It typically means we are laughing and they get a pet 
out of the encounter. If I say ack to them however they respond 
differently. They know that ack is serious and they better stop what they 
are doing.
comments.author: Amy Booth

comments.text:

and it was just not good.  That´s for what I asked you. It´s more 
time-saving than spend a year watching all videos and hope I´ll find my 
answer there. :-) Anyway, your dogs are great amazing and unspeakably 
beautiful and I probably will watch all the videos, but I wanted to know 
more about this. :-)

at around the 0:53 second mark i noticed that you have a nitro rc buggy, do

comments.author: . “Colinator4321”

comments.text:
+Colin Velt Though I'm not the one you asked, I'd like to offer an opinion. 
While nitro's are awesome for having actual engines, they are loud, and 
they are dirty (the oils suspended in the exhaust fumes get everywhere), so 
if you're a diligent owner (which I'm not), you'll want to painstakingly 
clean the whole thing after every use. Then you need to readjust the 
carburetor every time there's a major change in temperature. You have to 
always carry a spare glow plug around with you, and if the engine stalls, 
there's always the hassle of taking the body off and the danger of burning 
your fingers. 
And if the dogs go after the buggy, they're all the more in danger of 
inhaling the nasty exhaust gases (if they make my eyes and nose itch, when 
I get too close, I don't want to know how that feels for a dog). And of 
course you can't drive around without the body, or your dog will probably 
burn its nose on the muffler sooner or later.
Also, when you've got to refuel, you'll be handling a rather toxic liquid 
with your dogs probably jumping around in excitement next to you, and you 
know how some dogs like to sample literally everything that could possibly 
be bad for them.
comments.author: Motorsheep

comments.text:
+Gone to the Snow Dogs  understandable, but may i ask what about the nitro 
one makes you want to go electric, do the dogs not chase it or are you 
having problems with the engine. ive heard people have proplems with exceed
